title: RIOT GIVE SOME CONTEXT ON THE LEE BUFFS
body:
Why is the guy who manages to be decent and consistently picked in adverse meta getting buffed? 
There are so many underwhelming champions that haven't seen daylight in years, he's just been just a bit above average for 3 months and he needs buffs?

replies.body:
These are buffs intended to give power particularly to players who aren't amazing at Lee Sin. We like that Lee Sin's got a pretty steep mastery curve that really rewards practice, but it's a bit too extreme, making it really hard to put him in a good spot balance wise (if he's balanced in top tier play he's very weak for the average player, if he's at least tolerable for the average player he's probably too dominant in top tier play). They will add a bit of power to competitive Lee Sin play too, we're looking to avoid too much of a buff there though.

As far as the specific changes go:

* Ult now deals damage to people hit by the champion knocked back based off the bonus HP of the champ kicked. If you can Insec well, this isn't going to be a very appealing play generally. If you can't however, and are regularly using the ult just to get enemy divers out of the fight for your team this will offer a bit of extra power to try and optimize. Will be some niche cases where it helps out in high level play as well, we expect those situations to be pretty niche though.

* Energy restore from passive now frontloaded onto the first auto attack (20 first auto then 10 second auto, instead of 15/15). This buff will help out both new and experienced Lee Sin players, expectation is it'll be significantly more useful to newer players though as they learn energy management and when to weave auto attacks in between spell casts. A frequent source of failure we see from new players is constantly trying to weave in 2 autos per cast, even when that's a really poor idea or, at the other extreme, running out of energy frequently. Giving people room to learn and grow's great of course, we'd like to get some signalling in there to encourage people to consider 1 auto per cast more often when they're first learning though.

>These are buffs intended to give power particularly to players who aren't amazing at Lee Sin. 

"We want to reward Lee even when he fucks up"
"Instead of actually balancing him."

'Balanced for who?' is one of the questions behind this work. We choose to balance for high level play, with some reigning in of massive outliers at lower skill levels. If the difference in performance between experienced and inexperienced player gets too far out of line however that means we're forced to make a champion really hard to succeed with and unsatisfying for the average player if they're to be balanced at high level play. Making a champions skill floor a bit more accessible, without lowering their skill ceiling, is an approach we feel's valuable as a result, and this work is, in part, an example of that.

Not a rage comment but what about the OP's second part of this thread that talks about him being prioritized over other champions in a bad spot.

I.E. Yorick

5.16's also got changes to a number of other champs we believe also need some help. Currently in testing stuff includes:

Kassadin (ult AP ratio)
Le Blanc (partial reversion of the W speed reduction)
Lissandra (self cast ult heals Lissandra) 
Lucian (W MS bonus can now be triggered by allies)
Nami (buffed passive, ult applies double strength passive)
Twitch (lower Q mana cost and very slight ult damage increase late game)
Vel'koz (secondary missiles on Q have more range)
Zed (shorter delay until ult can be reactivated)

That's all potential stuff in testing, so not guaranteed to go live of course, but Lee's definitely not the only champ we're looking at in that regard.

Yorick's a champ we believe needs a full kit overhaul, in the same way old Sion did/Poppy does. He's not in a terrible spot power wise so, given we don't believe he's good for the game, we don't want to add any power to him at this point.

As this is a straight up buff (and not a shifting of power in the abilities) it really isn't a balance made for high level of play. It's a buff on all levels of play.

> unsatisfying for the average player

This clearly isn't the case with Lee Sin as he already has a massive popularity, so if this is so important why choose Lee Sin as the subject of this buff?

Earlier arguments  (from non game designers though, such as Phreak, but still Riot answers) regarding why Lee Sin is allowed so much special attention has been that that Lee Sin is a great design because he is so fun to play and that his popularity has nothing to do with his power level.

>Making a champions skill floor a bit more accessible, without lowering their skill ceiling, is an approach we feel's valuable as a result, and this work is, in part, an example of that.

So you're going to balance him at low levels and break him in higher level play? This seems like a very poor solution to me.

You'd better be planning to nerf what makes him so powerful in high level play at the same time because otherwise you're going to have an incredibly broken champion on your hands

That's what this change will do though, you're a fool if you think this doesn't help Lee out at high levels of play too.

You forgot about the part in which he gets multiple indirect buffs due to armor nerfs.

The only real skill involved in playing Lee ends up not being useless past the 20 minute mark. Overtuning his damage - especially because the unfavorable for him meta shifts - isn't the answer to that.

Lee's already relatively balanced, bordering on being too strong though, not too weak. 

He's already a very viable jungler who see's fair amounts of competitive play and he's the most popular jungler in terms of solo que.

Buffing him in a patch that already greatly favours him is a terrible idea.

The only thing that you can call "balance" about Lee Sin is the fact he becomes a nigh non-factor past 20-25th minute of the game if you can't do the inSec.

But before that he's like Shaco, who can decide the game in 10 minutes to the point basically playing 4v5 isn't an issue.

I'm inclined to more or less agree with this TBH.

I feel he's more or less balanced by how hard he falls off, but that doesn't make him well designed. I feel Lee's design is amongst the worst of any champ in the game's.

> "We want to reward Lee even when he fucks up"

That isn't even close to what he was talking about.

Right now Lee Sin has a high skill floor, and for players still getting the hang of them it's easy to be and feel utterly useless, as a new Lee Sin player isn't going to be able to ward hop as quickly, jump in or out, or get to the back line etc, a lot of ults by him from an average player are just Lee Sins kicking the champion who dives their team, reducing his effectiveness further.

All these buffs serve to do is lower his skill floor a bit, he isn't being rewarded when he fucks up, I don't even get how you came up with that, if he is fucking anything up he isn't hitting his ult in the firstplace.

I get people hate Lee Sin on these forums, but he isn't perfect and has plenty of problems that can be fixed, it's isn't a coincidence the entire season 5 had no one complaining on the forums about him, he is fine.

It does help out Lee in scenarios where he misplays, most notably where his team gets engaged on.

The buffs create a scenario where Lee can counter engage far too well, as he can kick the enemy tank back into their own team, nuking everyone who they hit and applying a knock-up to them.

Personally I'd argue that being in a position where the enemy team can engage on you is in and of itself a fuck up, and Lee is clearly being rewarded for that fuck up with these buffs.

Thanks, Riot.

Like I sorta felt there was a reason for micromanaging his passive probably for more damage but a tradeoff would be his high base damage on his Q and R so he isn't so full AD reliant.

I mean he's got an interesting kit with a variety of uses. But I feel he should need to stick in battle to pummel a lot of damage.

In my over 3 1/2 years of playing this game, there has never been a time where Lee Sin wasn't at least acceptable in the meta if you were talented with him. He does NOT needs buffs, lol

>Why is the guy who manages to be decent and consistently picked in adverse meta getting buffed?
There are so many underwhelming champions that haven't seen daylight in years, he's just been just a bit above average for 3 months and he needs buffs?

Just to add to this Riot's also nerfing the hell out of armour in the same patch, which is greatly in Lee's favour and gutting Cinderhulk just to make sure his competition isn't as strong.
and nidalee nerfs, so you know the top junglers are all taken care of

They are also buffing the armor gained per level for all the tanks.

The armor nerfs themselves are minor. As well as a lot of costs for some of the items being reduced.

Cinderhulk changes make it a buff early/mid while being hardly different late game.

They're only buffing some tanks though, where does this leave Sejuani for example? She's a tank who's already suffering after an incredibly overkill set of nerfs and she's not getting any armour buffs.

>Cinderhulk changes make it a buff early/mid while being hardly different late game.

In practice it works the opposite way for most tanks. Your mid game's so weak that you don't really care about the small increase (It caps at +90 HP if you're not running any other HP at all) and you just end up losing out on HP late game.

Personally when I play a tank I'd much prefer 50 extra HP at lv 16 to 100 at lv 6. You need as much late game power as you can get on tanks.

They are upping the base HP by 100, this is a massive buff for it, by late game you get less then 100HP shaved off your 3500 total, you won't even notice the difference.

And {{champion:113}} isn't suffering she got knocked down a peg and is still seeing high play, and high ban rates.

They're upping the base HP by 100, but Cinder multiplies it's own HP, 25% of 300 is 75 meaning ATM Cinder gives 375 HP, on the PBE it gives 460, which is a 85 HP difference, assuming 0 HP from runes and masteries.

With 2k bonus HP there's a 100 HP difference,  old Cinder being better, but some tanks (like Sej) stack more than 2k bonus HP quite often.

And Sej is suffering, she's not even a competitive pick any more.
